B00000JPHF|4.0|*** Contains mild/vague spoilers ***<BR> Mary Shelley's Gothic novel, Frankenstein, was transformed into a black and white motion picture in 1931, but the book still provides us with a better \\"cautionary tale against overweening presumption\\" (Shelley iii). Although James Whale's adaptation of Shelley's masterpiece is, as 1930's movies go, a wonderful specimen it could never eclipse the brilliance and talent of the author's original story.<BR> The first of the many inconsistancies begins almost immediately. The picture's introduction, by the renowned \\"Dracula\\" actor, Bela Lugosi, was mysterious and ominous. The book's introduction, written by Mary Shelley, is calm and realistic. Shelley's tale of a \\"hideous phantasm of a man\\" (viii) is written in a way that can almost be believed, where as the movie is quite the opposite. To be led by the hand into a world that Lugosi openly admits to being fictional, and as he implies, impossible is one thing. To have the door thrown wide open to a horrible premonition of what might be, what very well could be... Ah, blissful terror.<BR> Whale's \\"Frankenstein\\" includes minute changes that are often bemusing. The change of names for example, Shelley's Victor Frankenstein becomes Henry Frankenstein and Victor's best friend Henry, now called Victor, recieves its own share of blinks and blank stares but does not altogether ruin the experience. However, adding tedious and unnecessary details where once there were only obscure hints dims the allure and quiets the terror one feels when confronted with the mystery of the novel and the creature's unknown origins. Whale unvieled the secrets that the audience did not want to hear and spoiled the delicious bite of fear, the tingle that comes when something goes, \\"Bump!\\" in the dark of night.<BR> There are a few more changes which will inevitably bring ire to the forefront. In James Whale's own \\"Frankenstein\\" little can be said of the ending, except that it is typically trite in true Hollywood form. If Whale's \\"Frankenstein\\" were as interesting in body, had been as full and complex as the real Frankenstein is then maybe the final product would be a little less miserably happy. <BR> Something else to irritate a critic would be the lack of secrecy, the missing solitude of our tragic heros, that we find in Mary Sheley's Modern Prometheus, but which is absent from Whale's \\"Frankenstein.\\" From the very beginning of the motion picture Victor \\"Henry\\" Frankenstein is not alone in he knowledge that such an abomination exists, or even that this abomination is own own first son. James Whale brings to the laboratory the professor, the best friend, and the fiance. It is with their help that Victor bears tragedies that follow his Monster's abnormal birth, but these tragedies do not touch so close to our main character's heart as the did previously. <BR> In the end it lies with the critic, with the reader, with the viewer. The question is not which piece is the better work, or even which artist is better creator, the question is for those who pick up the book and play the movie. The question is yours to answer. Are you more suited to Hollywood's happy endings and rose colored glasses? Or are you willing - nay, eager, to walk into Mary Shelley's sorrow, her grief, her wild terror and mind numbing horror? Watch the movie, then read the book. It it my personal opinion that proceeding in the opposite order would be unwise, you would spoil the movie.
B00008S2VG|5.0|This album is unlike any Madonna album!  That's what makes her talented and on top of music artistry.  Too many critics (and close-minded fans alike) are writing this album off as meaningless but what Madonna accomplished here is a collection of straight-from-the-heart musings on love (Nothing Fails, Intervention) and spirituality (X-Static Process).  Like Ray of Light and it's focus on the awakening thoughts of Hinduism and Budhism, this record brings forth the simple yet powerful principles of the Kabbalah (Love Profusion, Nobody Knows Me, Die Another Day).  There's no fluff here and that's evident with the pop stylings and deep rooted lyrical review of parental failings (Mother & Father).  On top of it all, Madonna emphasises what we will all come to know at some point in life (American Life, Hollywood, I'm So Stupid, Easy Ride)...that the material life the human race is so fond of will ultimately mean nothing!  Stop the comparisons to other albums as this record stands alone as a subtle yet masterful work.

B00003CXI0|5.0|For a lot of reasons, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is probably a tempting movie to criticize.  After all, there is almost nothing a critic hates more than a film that is practically - baring some unforgivable act of gross incompetence - a guaranteed success, despite anything he or she might happen to write about it.<br />At any rate, while some may quibble with the notion that Sorcerer's Stone is too much like the book that inspired it, the upside for moviegoers is that neither Rowling nor director Christopher Columbus have forgotten the film's primary audience: young readers between the ages of 12 - 16.  For those whose parents read the book to them, the age may actually drop a bit below that.  <br />For the most part, as every parent knows, it is an audience frequently patronized with the worst sort of infantile pap imaginable, inundated with coarse language and gratuitous violence, or simply ignored altogether.  Columbus, to his credit, does none of the above.  In remaining true to his audience, Columbus has, in fact, delivered a film for all of us.<BR> <BR>It is obvious Columbus knows, for instance, that a young audience wants to see on the screen what it read in the book.  In pursuit of this goal, Columbus and screenwriter Steve Kloves have fashioned characters and settings true to the letter and the spirit of the novel. The characters, especially, strike just the right chord of familiarity.  Certainly, we all know that familiarity can wander over the line into disinterested comfort. Remarkably, the characters in Sorcerer's Stone never do.  Robbie Coltrane's Hagrid, for instance, looks just as we expect him to.  More important, he radiates a warmth and trust that serves as a secure anchor in those moments when events seem to be spinning out of control.  As good as Hagrid is in the book, Coltrane's Hagrid is more vivid on the screen.<BR> <BR>Which brings us to the performance of Daniel Radcliffe in the role of Harry Potter.  At first glance, Radcliffe seems reticent and withdrawn, hidden behind a gauze curtain, an uncertain hero. Yet we cannot forget that Harry Potter is an eleven year-old orphan whose parents have been murdered. He is a foundling whose caretakers resent his existence and actively disapprove of everything he is and, worse, in their own eyes, everything he will become. He is forced to sleep in a closet under the stairs and absorb a constant stream of verbal and physical abuse from his malevolent aunt and uncle and their overindulged son, Dudley.  <br />Yes, of course Harry is withdrawn.  Small wonder. Or, as my daughter would say, \\"Duh!\\"  <br />In fact, Radcliffe's performance is entirely consistent with Harry's history and upbringing, and Columbus has wisely ensured that, as the chronicle of films progresses, the character of Harry has somewhere to go. There are, after all, six movies still to come. Columbus has clearly determined that, unlike some other celluloid heroes of recent memory (Indiana Jones springs to mind), the character of Harry Potter should have some room to develop, otherwise both the young wizard and his friends would grow quickly stagnant.<br />Another notable attribute of the film is that the atmosphere and setting, through the more subtle elements of special effects, are beautifully realized. As the first-years are journeying across the lake, their - and our - first view of Hogwarts Castle is absolutely breathtaking, a spectacular, gothic memory from a medieval dream.  Inside the castle are stairways that move, pictures that talk and go about their daily routines, and a splendid dining hall that evokes the grandeur of a cathedral.  When the Sorting Hat pronounces \\"GRIFFINDORE\\" on this opulent stage, Harry's adventures officially begin.<br />Yes, the adventure has its obvious, special effects masterpieces. The Quidditch match is a high-flying, fast-paced extravaganza of soccer, polo, and basketball on broomsticks. The chess match is the high point of the film.  At the same time, there are special effects so well done that they don't draw attention to themselves. The messenger owls flying gracefully into the dining hall to deliver envelopes and parcels is a brief, finely structured, aerial ballet that is easy to take for granted because we are momentarily suspended in the world of Hogwarts and have willingly cast aside our powers of disbelief.  When Hedwig flies above Hogwarts Castle, our spirits and our sense of wonder soar with him. It is an impressive accomplishment.   <br />Because it is true to itself and never panders to its audience, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is both exciting and entertaining, an escape to a world where magical things can still happen. It is, in short, a film for the child in all of us.

0385504209|2.0|Dan Brown can certainly write a gripping thriller and the book is hard to put down with non-stop action from beginning to end. What a pity, then, that he has wanted to use the Da Vinci Code to write an anti-Christian tract. Particular venom is reserved for the Catholic Church, or \\"the Vatican\\" as the author likes to call it, somewhat anachronistically when he is speaking of the Church in the 4th Century AD. The references to Opus Dei are so inaccurate that it is virtually impossible to recognise the organisation as it exists in real life. 0688163173|5.0|First there were the noir detective books. Then &quot;Mystic River&quot;, which was 70-80% different. &quot;Shutter Island&quot; is a 100% switch from either of those. I was fortunate enough to purchase mine at a book signing where Lehane answered questions for about an hour. He has taught writing extensively and is a very patient, cordial and articulate inverview (not all writers speak well). Lehane said something that helps understand all his work, but especially this one. He said his stories are about people who strive and strive for what they want, only to wind up with what they need instead, and is makes their soul whole. &quot;Shutter Island&quot; is a very tight (we know what the main character, Teddy, knows - period), freightening story. Still, Lehane laces his outstanding literary skills and fantastic story line with his usual humorous passages, and his wonderful, punchy descriptive metapors. &quot;Shutter Island&quot; is not literally a haunted castle story. All the characters are &quot;real&quot; (human) and there are no ghosts or other-world beings. But it is absolutely, positively the best haunted castle tale I have ever read. This book goes on my list of all-time favorites.
6303607942|5.0|This is not Horowitz's best reading of the Rach 3, but it is still considerably better than any other pianist.  If I understand correctly, this was the second half of a concert, the first half having consisted of a solo recital by Horowitz.  For some reason the first movement is a little nervy.  There are some memory slips and a few smudges, but after mopping his brow at the end of it Horowitz settles down nicely in the second and third movements.  The playing is really very good, although one sees the point that Rubinstein made when he watched this live telecast that the conductor &quot;poor Zubin Mehta&quot; had to work hard to follow Horowitz's varying tempi.  While there are some wonderful moments in this performance, there are also some dreadful ones, particularly the octaves at the end of the third movement where orchestra and soloist are painfully out of sync.  However, the camera work is first class and some of the close-ups of the Horowitz's fingers are fascinating.<br />To sum up, an excellent recording, not Horowitz's best but very enjoyable and fascinating to watch.  Also, there are no cuts in this performance.  Horowitz's practice (and Rachmaninoff's) was to cut some sections out of the 2nd and 3rd movements, but here is one of the very few Horowitz recordings of the whole composition.
B00008BRDX|4.0|With the 1979 release of &quot;Regatta de Blanc&quot; (White Reggae) The Police left their punk pretensions behind and established themselves as a New Wave force with chops and plenty of rock punch. If you only know Sting from his solo stuff, check out this early group material. The guy could flat out groove on the bass. Stewart Copeland has always been an outstanding drummer. Andy Summers is an underrated guitarist who serves as the glue of this band, and his washes and textures and odd chords are incredible. There's also a lot more collaboration in the songwriting than on later releases.<br />Right out of the gate we get the all-time classic &quot;Message in a Bottle&quot; with a deceptively simple rhythm line and the amazing timed drums that fill in the choruses. Sting turns around his &quot;me me&quot; lyrics in the final verse when the castaway realizes he's not the only lonely soul.<br />&quot;Regatta De Blanc&quot; is near-instrumental with a great groove.<br />&quot;It's Alright For You&quot; is a joint Copeland/Sting effort that has a punky edge, killer drums and cool guitar and bass fills.<br />&quot;Bring on the Night&quot; is an underrated gem of a song, with its rising guitar line, echoey drums, and one of my favorite lyrics, &quot;the afternoon has gently passed me by/evening spreads itself against the sky.&quot; Great reggae-tinged polorhythmic structure between the bass and drums.<br />&quot;Deathwish&quot; features some nifty time changes and cool guitar and drum interplay, especially Copeland's high-hat work.<br />&quot;Walking on the Moon&quot; is a definite 5-star tune, again with the bass and drums working in slightly different times. Sounds simple but it's deceptively tricky. The lyrics about new love have a certain weightlessness and joy...<br />&quot;On Any Other Day&quot; is a Stewart Copeland featuring his lead vocals and some hilarious lyrics of a guy having a bad one. Great aside lyric &quot;I'm covered in misery.&quot;<br />&quot;The Bed's Too Big Without You&quot; is another underrated gem similar to &quot;Bring on the Night&quot; with loopy guitars, pulsing drums, and a haunting bassline and vocal. Great lyrics by Sting.<br />&quot;Contact&quot; is a Copeland tune with some wry lyrics like &quot;I've got contacts in my book and in my eyes/my good connection on the telephone never lies&quot; and Stings bassline snakes all over the neck of his guitar.<br />&quot;Does Everyone Stare&quot; is a quirky little song with a piano/vocal intro and Sting singing in his lower register, then kicking it up an octave as the other instruments come in. &quot;I never noticed the size of my feet/til I kicked you in the shins...&quot;<br />&quot;No Time This Time&quot; has Sting taking things up a notch for the final tune. Good rocker.<br />I love the various dynamics The Police achieved on this album and the raw energy of their trio performance before they became an international sensation.hout You&quot; is another underrated gem similar to &quot;Bring on the Night&quot; with loopy guitars, pulsing drums, and a haunting bassline and vocal. Good rocker.<br />I love the various dynamics The Police achieved on this album and the raw energy of their trio performance before they became an international sensation.

B00000K19E|4.0|This is a good movie, but doesn't deserve the fanatical following it has.  Some reviewers below commented on the &quot;good story&quot; in the movie, but that is really it's weakest point.  There are so many holes in the plot and entire concept that you can't possibly do anything but go into suspended disbelief mode and ignore the so-called &quot;plot&quot; entirely.  <br />Other people talk about the &quot;innovative&quot; plot, too, but I've read science fiction books in the 1960's and 1970's that covered the same story line.  Sorry, guys, but there is very little new under the sun; the plot (such as it is) for this movie certainly isn't new in any sense of the word.<br />Another criticism that other people inexplicably argue with me over - the acting skills, and I use that phrase lightly, of Keanu Reeves.  He has improved a bit over his horrendous performance in &quot;Speed&quot;, but still, he is one of the worse actors in the business today.  Lawrence Fishburne's acting consists mainly of looking cool in his sunglasses, too.  He pulls it off, but it's not a challenging or engaging performance at all.  The best actor in the movie is Joe Pantoliano, who went on to be the gangster everyone loved to hate in &quot;The Sopranos&quot;.<br />So what does the movie have going for it?  Great innovative special effects, and for people who aren't heavy into the martial arts genre, good fight sequences.  Those of us who have been following martial arts movies BEFORE &quot;The Matrix&quot; and &quot;Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon&quot; have seen all this before, and done far better, too (Hong Kong has it all over Hollywood in this department).  But still, even though the actors have NO martial arts skills, the action sequences are reasonably well done.  That's a credit to Yuen Wo Ping, the fight coordinator.  Again, those of us in the know have been following his work for years.  Once again, nothing new...<br />The buzz for &quot;The Matrix - Reloaded&quot; is all about - what?  The special effects.  That says it all - no one cares about the story, they just want to see new and better FX and action sequences.  So I'm afraid the movie will be all about out-doing the original as far as action sequences and special effects go.  That's fine, but there needs to be more to it than that.  Well, then again, maybe there doesn't...<br />Now, the DVD.  In spite of my criticisms of the movie, this is still one of the best DVD productions, in some way, on the market.  The unfortunate part is the visual aspects of the movie.  The Wachowski brothers purposely made the movie dark, with very little color or detail.  So it is not reference quality, visually, at all.  Don't use this disk to show off your video system; it just doesn't deliver in that deparment.  But the audio is outstanding; one of the best sounding DVDs ever.  I'm surprised so few DVDs releases since this one have equalled it's audio quality.<br />So is this DVD worth buying?  If you have a good surround system, yes, absolutely.  Just don't try to follow the story - sit back and enjoy the action.

0194313425|5.0|I was first recommended this book by my English teacher when I was in high school.  I read it through and felt I got a pretty good idea about English grammar and English usage in general.  It was 15 years ago.  Since then I completed my undergraduate and graduate degrees in institutions where English was the language of instruction, and continue using English on work.  Often when I see grammar mistakes in writing or speaking, I realise that it was explained in this book and feel greatful what it taught me.  I have read many other grammar books but whenever I am not sure, I still go back to this book. My teacher who recommended me this book said exactly the same thing.  So I strongly recommend this book for foundation and referrence for English grammar, for those who have not found grammar book they are satisfied with.

B000002UY5|5.0|Strangely, I only rediscovered this album a couple of weeks ago, after it had remained dormant at the bottom of one of my many boxes of CD's. I bought it around it's UK release date after seeing the video for &quot;No Rain&quot; on MTV: like most people, who subsequently heard &quot;Change&quot;, I was taken in by the light-hearted, vaguely rocky-folky noises and the lilt of Shannon's voice (which I later discovered to be far weaker in a live setting than in a studio). <br />No doubt, the release of the two semi-accoustic songs on the album was a wonderful marketing ploy by a genial, grey-suited man in an office, but it worked wonders: the drums at the beginning of &quot;Soak the sin&quot; signalled a bold change from the overplayed singles which had been released, and when I heard the line &quot;What he says to do, is that we don't have to&quot; in the half-tempo passage, I knew that I had discovered something rather remarkable. &quot;Tones of home&quot; starts with that nice jazzy pizicatto guitar, and just makes you happy. &quot;I wonder&quot;, by far and away the best song on the album (and the song which defined the style for Soup) still sends shivers down my spine - just listen to the words of the first verse proper - I, too, would love to daze away... (with his overdose, Shannon later lived his dream.) <br />Other highlights on the album include &quot;Sleepyhouse&quot;, which invokes memories of all great summers, and &quot;Time&quot;, which rivals REM's &quot;Find the river&quot; as the greatest end to an album of all time. If you can get past the egotism of &quot;Dear ol' Dad&quot; and manage to recognise &quot;No Rain&quot; for what it is (the single to open doors) then you may find that this album changes your life. Few people in the nineties could write lyrics like Shannon Hoon ('I'm tired of me this way'; 'When you stop dreaming, it's time to die'), and few bands had such a solidified approach without having to be classed in altogether obsure genres. Take my advice - buying this album is a musical investment.
B000000OSG|5.0|This album is my alltime favorite of any of the rock albums I own.  The musical entegrity is astounding.  The songwriting also is far more mature than AFD was. Axls maturity level was greatly hired through the release of UYI and II.  Many GnR fans turn this album away as being to much of an artistic album rather than a straight foward rock album like I was.  But UYI II makes up for that and more.  Estranged (being my personal favorite) really is a soothing and low key masterpiece thought up by Axl.  The second half is more my type, beautiful lyrics, soothing ryhtyms and a kick ass solo via Slash (whos at his top game on this album).  Breakdown is my second favorite cut off the album.  It successfully merges heavy rock with a little country-influenced banjo.  Once again great GnR.  Pretty Tied Up, Breakdown, You Could Be Mine, Get In The Ring and Shotgun Blues deliever great hard rock tunes.  All very bold in whatever way implied.  Dont Cry is so gutwrenchingly-beautiful even I get teary!  14 years supplies great blues via Izzy Stradlin who's ryhtyms are a little undermined by Slashs mastery of hard rock riffs.  Civil War, Yesterdays, and So Fine break down the barrier for this record.  They ensure its genious through simple chord structures and lyrics and they pull it off.  No one can listen to those songs and think GnR sucks anymore :).  My World has grown on me but its not my cup of tea per say.<br />Buy this album.  Its worth EVERY cent.

B00008S2VG|5.0|After the massive success of her 2000 album &quot;Music&quot;, Madonna is back, with the most interesting and personal album of her career, &quot;American Life&quot;. I have been a fan of Madonna for many years now, and I must say, this is her best album to date. Every song is terrific, and for more reasons than one. First of all, many fans of Madonna will listen to this album for the first time, expecting to hear the typical Madonna musical form. That is a big mistake. This album is a total 360-degree turn away from anything else she has ever done in her career. This is certainly, a different Madonna. However, she changed for the better. Each song on the album has a deep, and mature meaning to it. The lyrics are very personal, as they deal with fame, materialism, family, loss, and of course... the American Life! All this is not to say that Madonna doesn't have fun with this album either. There are a few songs on the album that will make you want to dance around the house! This album shows a more mature, fun, and utterly talented Madonna. &quot;American Life&quot; will satisfy the ears of every Madonna fan! The Limited Edition comes packaged in a beautiful leather box. Inside the box is a beautiful two-sided poster, and a really cool, collectible Madonna Stamp Sheet. As someone who has heard every note Madonna has every sang, take it from me... &quot;this type of modern life&quot;, is certainly for you!
B000001IPP|5.0|As my title implies, I found this record to be rather light for a punk record, but I totally love this music.  The music is fun, fast, and catchy, and is always a good listen.  This record is more punky than ...And Out Come the Wolves (though that's not saying much), but no where near as punk as Rancid 2000 (my personal favorite).<br />These songs are really good, but, at first, they all kind of sound the same.  It takes a few listens, but, after a while, you start to notice the uniqueness of each song.  Once you realize how great of an album Let's Go is, you'll want to listen to it all the time.  It's got 23 songs on it, so it never gets boring.  This, ...And Out Come the Wolves, and Rancid 2000 are what I consider the essential Rancid purchases.  AOCTW has a punk/ska-ish, almost poppy kind of feel, while Rancid 2000 is pure punk, and Let's Go is sort of a median between the two.<br />Bottom Line: Great, sort of light punk record from the 90s.
B000002KMV|5.0|Although it often escapes into obscurity sandwiched between the legendary \\"Dirty Mind\\" and \\"1999,\\" \\"Controversy\\" is an astounding album in its own right.  Here, Prince extends his forays into the political realm notable in \\"Partyup\\" (from \\"Dirty Mind\\").  He has so much to say, and you'd better believe he's going to say it all in the short 37 minutes that form the duration of the album.  While at times this causes the music to sound a little forced and rushed (on the otherwise astounding \\"Sexuality\\" and the roaring \\"Ronnie Talk to Russia\\"), when Prince takes a little more time to extend the groove and elabroate, it works marvelously.  The title track remains one of Prince's most timeless, effortless anthems and truly epitomizes what he represents.  \\"Annie Christian\\" is a haunting, distorted song that paved the way for future stunners like \\"Something in the Water (Does Not Compute).\\"<br />Despite the overtly political messages, present on the songs mentioned above and the album sleeve, Prince delves into the world of sex quite successfully.  \\"Do Me, Baby,\\" the only track on which Prince takes his time, is a bedroom burner unrivaled in his extensive catalog.  The empassioned vocal delivery and slightly comical climax make it a classic.  \\"Let's Work\\" features Prince ABUSING his bass guitar with licks so tight that George Clinton would cringe in envy.  \\"Private Joy\\" bounces off the record with youthful exhuberance and energy and \\"Jack U Off\\" offers a tongue-in-cheek rockabilly ditty that is sure to delight (if not embarrass).<br />Prince may not have reached his peak at this point, but on \\"Controversy,\\" Prince displays not only unlimited potential, but some undeniable classics.  It is an oddball among Prince releases, but one that ages well and features some of his most telling material.
1400034779|4.0|First, I have to say that this is not a detective novel; at least, not in the traditional sense of having a murder take place at the end of the first chapter and then the rest of the book is spent by the detective solving the mystery. This is more of a novel with some snippets of mysteries thrown in for good measure. The writing style appears to be simple but as you read on, you realize that the prose is deceptively simple. There are layers beneath the surface that give an unexpected depth to the book. I find Precious Ramotswe, the \\"lady\\" of the Ladies' Detective Agency, to be an incredibly interesting character. She has suffered with a bad husband (now ex), the loss of a child, and the loss of a beloved father but is strong throughout and keeps her humanity intact. I cannot wait to read the further adventures.

B00005JKLZ|3.0|On the upside, this film turned out to be not nearly as bad as the reviews I had read would have led me to believe.  It had, in fact, a number of good aspects.  It was great to look at, and the special effects added considerably to the story.  Guy Pearce was good in the lead role, and Samantha Mumba was remarkably fetching as Mara, the woman he would meet 800,000 years in the future.<br />But there were just too many undeveloped or hard to swallow elements for this to be a good film, and it too often became merely unintelligible.  I have read Heidegger and Spinoza, Habermas and Derrida, Duns Scotus and Deleuze, so I can understand difficult texts and ideas when called to.  But there is a different between a merely difficult idea and an unintelligible one, and the central dilemma of this film--\\"Why can't I change the past?\\"--was dealt with in an unacceptably blithe and confused manner.  The \\"answer\\" as mouthed by Jeremy Irons, in a role that was more of a cameo than a real part, was unforgivably simplistic and superficial, not to say unconvincing.  But there were so many other moments that were so improbable that it was hard to take this movie seriously.  For instance, the Orlando Jones computer generated character appears not only in the early 21st century, but in the distant future as well, in the ruins of a former city.  What powered the computer that contained his database?  How did people hundreds of thousands of years in the future retain a perfect knowledge of the dead English language, and speak with a perfect accent?  How did our hero know that jamming the gears of his time machine would have the effect it would?  There were a host of other problems as well.<br />If you don't ask questions of this film, and don't expect it to deliver much, it can provide a couple of hours of delicious eye candy.  But if you try to force it to make sense, you will hate it.  In the former, you end up not taking it seriously, which is on one level to do it and its makers a disservice.  On the latter, however, you do them the compliment of taking the film seriously, but at the cost of condemning it.  I hope I can be forgiven for taking it as simple minded, light entertainment.sservice.  On the latter, however, you do them the compliment of taking the film seriously, but at the cost of condemning it.  I hope I can be forgiven for taking it as simple minded, light entertainment.

The people involved with baseball who aren't players are ex-players. In their defense, their structure is not set up along corporate lines. They aren't equipped to evaluate their own systems. They don't have the mechanism to let in the good and get rid of the bad. A perfect closer too. 5/5<br />Buy this. It's talked about so much, and there's a reason.

B00008WT5E|5.0|The one question every fan asks when remasters come out--&quot;Do I really need to buy another version of an album I already own?&quot;  When talking about AC/DC's reissued POWERAGE, the answer is undeniably yes.  Malcolm has said in interviews that these re-releases sound louder, and he's right!  From the first chords of the CD, the difference between this and previous versions is crystal clear.  The guitars are stark, then bass is rumbling, the drums have an extra snappiness to them, and Bon's voice sounds brilliant.<BR>To me, this is AC/DC's finest moment, both musically and lyrically.  With this new tweaking by the likes of Mike Fraser (who's sat in for the past two studio albums as engineer), this is sonically AC/DC's finest moment as well.<BR>Bottom line, if you are going to buy one re-issue from the Sony digipaks, let it be this one.  It's absolutely brilliant!!

0792833201|3.0|A lot of people complain that \\"The Ring\\" (my favorite horror movie) doesn't make sense. It does too- you just have to think about it. *Here*, however, is a movie that does not make sense. It's kind of fun, but ultimately just a bunch of random and increasingly eerie occurences, climaxing in a total freak-out. I don't understand how most of these strange happenings could be related to the Freelings building their house atop an old graveyard, particularly not that \\"powerful, angry soul\\" trip. Not only that, but the stupidity of the characters is remarkable (why the hell would you spend one last night in a haunted house before you move?). The special effects (which are not at all bad for 1982) are the best features. <BR>  I admit I was pretty scared while watching this movie, but as soon as it was over I realized the absurdity of the whole thing. The fear did not stick with me for even half an hour (unlike \\"The Ring\\", which has tempted me to sleep with my lights on every night since I watched it). To make matters worse, \\"Poltergeist\\" is nearly two hours long, and to me seemed to last about twice that amount of time. Trust me, there are better ways to spend your time.
B000000W9Z|5.0|I am generally not a fan of \\"concept\\" albums.  These albums require full listens in order to experience the whole story.  I'm more of a casual music lover.  That said, you simply have to listen to Outside one time from beginning to end in order to fully appreciate it.   Bowie's tale revolves around the theme of death as an artform.  Specifically, the ritualistic murder of a 14 year-old girl at the end of the 20th century, and its investigation by a private eye.  It's a dark tale that is taken to disturbing extremes in some places (Wishful Beginnings, specifically), but is somewhat lightened by some truly humorous pieces.  Also taking some of the edge off of the story is the passing of the year 2000.  The pre-millennial anxieties in the story have been rendered ineffective with the dawn of the new millennium 2 years ago.<BR>  There is quite a bit more to the story, but all in all, I think that \\"Outside\\" is exponentially more enjoyable as a simple collection of songs, and I recommend listening to it as such after 1 complete listen.   <BR>    Musically, \\"Outside\\" is another collaboration between Bowie and Brian Eno (the \\"berlin\\" trilogy of Heroes, Low, and Lodger were past collaborations).  Eno is a pioneer in electronic music and he is arguably one of the most creative artists in all of music. It shows here.  All conventions were obviously set aside when writing this album.  It is as unconventional and experimental as Radiohead's \\"Kid A\\" and \\"Amnesiac\\" albums would prove to be 4 years later,  but I find \\"Outside\\" to be far more interesting and enjoyable.  Though it's classified as a \\"rock\\" album, \\"Outside\\" contains elements of electronica, jazz, funk, grunge, industrial, and pop in nearly every single song.  It is perhaps the most eclectic album I've ever experienced.  It is definately unlike anything that I've ever heard before.  This unfamiliarity can be daunting.  The first time I heard \\"Outside\\", it literally exhausted me.  The combination of the demented story and the unfamiliar eeriness of the music took me to a place somewhere between depression, fear, and utter euphoria.  I was intrigued.  I perservered. I listened again.   I didn't begin to enjoy \\"Outside\\" until I became familiar with each track.  It's strange.  There have been albums that have \\"grown on me\\" in the past, but \\"Outside\\" continues to do so with each listen, even 7 years later.  It's a great collection of some of Bowie's greatest songs ever recorded.  The backstory is always there, but I again advise you to use it only as a means to give meaning to the lyrics of the individual songs.  \\"Outside\\" is a phenominal album that you simply have to experience.  It ranks among my top 10 favorites of all time.  It's more than enough to make me forgive the whole \\"Tin Machine\\" thing.

This is an unbelievable CD, crazily diverse at moments sappy and others brash and noisy but always very cool and masterfully played by all involved. If you are a musician running out of ideas or in a dry spell (I don't care what you play) this will save your life.

Girl Interrupted is Kaysen's memoir of two years spent in an expensive and exclusive psychiatric unit, previous guests having been Sylvia Plath, James Taylor, and Ray Charles, among others.<BR>The wit, wisdom, wackiness, and lyricism of 'a madhouse' come through clearly in the author's writing, and she offers vivid and insightful accounts of daily life, her fellow 'guests,' and the link between art and madness which often manifests itself in manic depression, or as we have lately been taught to say, Bipolar Disorder.<BR>A good read, and a pretty good movie...

This is the story of Pi and an elegant and monstrous Royal Bengal Tiger, both of them are entrapped in a lifeboat, the struggle for survival, outmaneuvering nature and clinging on the ingenuity of instinct and his steadfast belief in multiple faiths, namely, Hinduism, Christianity and Islam, makes this story a memorable one. <br />Along with its serious theme of life and death, this novel is quite funny as well. Pi's earlier childhood was full of nostalgic memories in the middle of a zoo that his father owned. There was the atheist teacher who opens Pi's eyes on nature the way he never had seen before. Pi's successive journey to a Church, Mosque and a Temple, made him embrace each of these religions simultaneously. For Pi, each of these religions offered him a sense of peace that he did not wish to renounce by accepting any one specific religion and denouncing others. And Atheism had its own appeal to him as well. <br />If you read one book this summer, read this one. This is an unforgettable novel.

B000083E79|5.0|A pillar of pop culture since the 60s, Cher has had many compilations released over the years in her name, but none were as definitive as this 2003 release 'The Very Best Of Cher'. Gathering songs from every era, from her days as duet partner to Sonny Bono to her recent role as club music queen, this collection is the perfect sampler of Cher hits for the casual fan and a perfect starter for new fans.<BR>  The album opener is Cher's number one dance smash 'Believe', from her 1998 album of the same name. Other cuts present from that album are diva anthems 'Strong Enough' and 'All Or Nothing'. Her most recent studio album 'Living Proof' yields the powerful 'Song For The Lonely' and the Rodney 'Darkchild' Jerkins remix of 'Different Kind Of Love Song'. Her mid-90s club classic 'One By One', remixed by the notorious Junior Vasquez, is also featured.<BR>  Some of her best rock pop hits from the late 80s into the early 90s also put on a good show here, the most easily recognized being the Diane Warren penned power pop of 'If I Could Turn Back Time'. The hits 'Just Like Jesse James' and 'Save Up All Your Tears' also feature the words of Ms. Warren. Michael Bolton turned out the suprisingly excellent 'I Found Someone' for Cher, while she duets with Peter Cetera on the ballad 'After All'. 'Heart Of Stone' proves to be another strong rocker, as this era for Cher closes with her infectious take on the classic 'The Shoop Shoop Song (It's In His Kiss)'.<BR>  In the early 70s, Cher released three of her all time best singles - 'Gypsies, Tramps, & Thieves', 'Half-Breed', and 'Dark Lady'. Incredibly catchy with an interesting story behind each track, all three went to number one on the Billboard chart. In the late 70s she mounted the first of many comebacks however, this time with a disco record called 'Take Me Home'. This record was a top ten hit, and was more recently reworked by British pop star Sophie Ellis-Bextor into her solo debut single 'Take Me Home (A Girl Like Me)'.<BR>Cher started her career as singing partner and wife to the late Sonny Bono, creating the undeniable classics 'I Got You Babe' and 'The Beat Goes On', both of which are featured here. While she sang with Sonny, she did manage to do a few solo songs as well, two of which make the cut here - 'All I Really Wanna Do' and 'Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)'. An excellent beginning to an epic music career.<BR>   Widely varied and always good, Cher is perhaps the only star who could been called the Queen of Pop before the likes of Madonna made her appearance in the 80s. Truly a musical original, and this album illustrates that perfectly. A must buy!
B00008AWOD|4.0|'Sleeping With Ghosts' is actually a very good albume; it contains a lot of good songs, which include (in my opinion) 'Special Needs', 'English Summer Rain', 'Sleeping With Ghosts' and 'Centrefolds'. However, there are some songs in the albume, that you just skip, and not listen at all. It's not that they're terrible music, but it's just not as original, and moving as the songs I mentioned. That is why my satisfaction becomes partial.<br />Placebo has always had an indie style; a lot of the sounds they produced had some unconventional quality to them. And that's what we like about them, maybe. Therefore, 'Sleeping With Ghosts' is lovable, in this sense, that it is Placebo's most indie-like albume. Brian Molko adds the piano's affective sound to the songs even more beautifullably. 'Special Needs' and 'Centrefolds' are one of these songs. I agree with the other reviewers that 'Centrefolds' resembles 'Blue American' or 'Peeping Tom' rather, that it has a closing, ending atmosphere to it, which makes the song even more saddening than ever.<br />'English Summer Rain' and 'Sleeping With Ghosts' are really moving songs. These songs really take you away. 'The Bitter End' and 'Protect Me From What I Want' are more intense songs, that sometimes become intolerable. Some songs, such as 'Something Rotten' contain too much electronic sounds and effects. I think they make the songs a little artificial and futuristic; this causes the albume to lose its emotional effect at one level.<br />Overall, if the question is whether you should buy the albume or not, I will say 'if you really want to...' Real Placebo fans, will not be able to refrain themselves from purchasing the albume, either. No, I think the albume's worth listening and having. But, you might also want to take your friend's cd, listen to it for a while, and return it. For those who haven't listened to Placebo yet: buy 'Without You I'm Nothing' first, to see how the group's music was initially; since it has differed in 'Sleeping With Ghosts' a lot.
6304057709|5.0|With an engaging plot, witty dialogue, and consummate acting by an all-star British cast (there really isn't one performance that could even be described as mediocre here!), this is one of the most delightful films I've seen.  Emma Thompson received a well-deserved Oscar for this splendid screen adaption of Jane Austen's classic novel.  Indeed, it is rare that I enjoy a dramatisation more than the novel, but I must confess that I did so here. <br />This is a story about love and propriety in early 19th-century England, and it follows a chapter in the lives of the two eldest Dashwood sisters, Elinor (Emma Thompson) and Marianne (Kate Winslet).  Their lives (together with those of their mother (Gemma Jones) and youngest sister) have been thrown into disarray by the death of their father (Tom Wilkinson), whose estate has been left to his son by a previous marriage (James Fleet--The Vicar of Dibley's Hugo).  At a time when money not only was equated with privilege and power but was essential for one's very survival, Elinor and Marianne, having neither an independent income nor dowries, are in the unenviable position (unlike Austen's Emma) of having to make a good marriage whilst having little but their appearance and personalities to recommend them. <br />Marianne, however, (the younger of the two) is an impetuous, idealistic romantic, for whom love must be some great all-consuming passion or it simply isn't love.  She wears her heart on her sleeve, and when \\"love\\" strikes in the dashing form of the dynamic Mr. Willoughby (Greg Wise) whom she takes to be a kindred spirit, she succumbs to her emotions.  Her overwhelming passion leads her to lose all common sense and act with reckless impropriety.  <br />Marianne's love is of the kind idealised by the Romantic poets and authors of the time (of which Austen was NOT one!)--the kind of love which cares not a toss for propriety, reputation or other societally imposed values.  It is also, alas, oblivious to boring monetary concerns such as wealth or poverty--concerns which in the cold light of day (and as the story bears out) few could disregard for all their talk to the contrary, and which were ultimately the deciding factor in many a marriage.   <BR>  <BR>Realistic rather than romantic, Elinor is of a calmer, more reserved nature, and not the sort to indulge in her emotions.  Indeed, if any fault can be found with her behaviour, it is that she is, perhaps, a little too reserved as even the object of her affections is unaware of her true feelings!  That said, she behaves sensibly, with dignity, and with concern for others, regardless of what she may be feeling inside (and this is also true of the gentlemen in the story--the real gentlemen, that is--played by Alan Rickman and Hugh Grant).  <br />Though set some 200 years ago, this is truly a film of timeless value.  If you've enjoyed the Firth/Ehle version of Pride and Prejudice in particular or you enjoy period productions in general, you'll definitely want to check this one out.  But it's such a good film all around--clean, warm-hearted and with plenty of comic relief--that I believe it's appeal is broad enough to be enjoyed by anyone looking for quality entertainment that the whole family can enjoy.  I thoroughly enjoyed it and recommend it most highly, and I look forward to reading the companion book: The Sense and Sensibility Screenplay and Diaries by Emma Thompson.

B000050IE6|5.0|Ahem...<BR>Have you ever discovered something so astoundingly great, entirely unexpectedly that you where totally blown away? <BR>That's exactly what happened with me when I got this album. <BR>I had developed an interest in the Metal and was going through the big metal bands catalogs when I noticed the reviews for this album and downloaded 'The Moor '.<BR>Oh boy!!!<BR>From the first listen I knew that this was a band that surpassed anything in that I had heard before. Opeth have a great heavy sections and their acoustic passages have a kind of exquisitetexture and depth I have not heard in any other band. Michael's death vocals sound like the roar of a lion (...R0AAARRRRRRRR) unlike those in other death bands which sound like the YAAW...RRRRR of a cat(eg Children of Bodom, which is not to say that they are bad).<BR>It is due to Still Life being my first Opeth album and the story in it being more easily understandable than MAYH or Blackwater Park that I consider this my favourite. All the songs in the album are excellent (though Serenity Painted Death ends quite abruptly). The music of Opeth could be best described as a sort of transtional metal, with the different tunes melding seamlessly with one another. This is done best in the Morningrise album but is as prevalent here as any other Opeth album. The album is best heard at a stretch but I'll still give a trackwise breakdown,<br />1. The Moor - The brilliant opener to a brilliant album, this begins with a long quiet solo which gives way to an acoustic passage which moves to an awesome heavy riff. Then come the heavy vocals which quite appropriately reflect the mood of the protagonist on his return to the village form where he was outcasted and humiliated. Then the clean vocals come in with some of the best lyrics to this point. This was the song that introduced me to Opeth and is my favourite on this album - 5/5<BR>2. Godhead's Lament - Any other band given the riff that begins this song would use it as the main riff throughout the song. Opeth on the other hand porgress to show how poor it really is by following it with a barrage of even better riffs. The clean vocals on this song are really striking - 5/5<BR>3. Benighted  - This track quite experimental and one of the relatively weaker tracks in the album, but it picks up toward the end as you start to get the tune, and it falls into place with the start of drumming - 4/5 <BR>(Note:The tracks Still Day Beneath the Sun, and Patterns in the Ivy II from the second disc of the Blackwater Park album are similar but much better)<BR>4. Moonlapse Vertigo - By this time Opeth have served up so many great melodies that you would think they would have exhausted their resources. No sir!!! - 5/5<BR>5. Face of Melinda - this song has an extruciating pacing that I really love about Opeth. It starts out mellow and acoustic and ends with one of the most electrifying riffs ever. This is song gives a stronger kick than an out and out headbanger even without trying - 5 + awesome outro riff/5 <BR>6. Serenity Painted Death - this is a heavy song appropriately reflecting the violence in the lyrics. Another good song but, ends quite disconcertingly in mid-flight - 4/5<BR>7. White Cluster - this is one of the most accesible songs in the album despite being really heavy. You really have to watch out for what happens after the 5:30 mark. Godly - 5/5<br />Whatever I said in this review doesn't even begin to do justice to this album, I don't really like to act as a raving fanboy but Opeth really have me hooked.<BR>The value of five stars is really brought down when most bands get it. On the other hand giving 5 stars for this album is really depreciating its value. Get this album, I beg, plead and coerce you, all for your sake, GET this album.

B000001EHS|3.0|[BEFORE I START THIS REVIEW, THIS CD IS THE ONE THAT INTRODUCED ME TO DEF LEPPARD. I AM A HUGE DEF LEPPARD FAN AND WHILE THIS CD IS A DECENT INTRODUCTION, I FEEL IT DOESN'T DO THE BAND JUSTICE. KEEP THIS IN MIND.]<BR><BR>     Now that aside, I just want to say \\"wow\\". I don't think I could have been introduced to D.L. any other way than with Vault. While \\"Vault\\" is highly controversial by many fans as being the \\"overloaded hysteria song\\" album, I have come to the conclusion that you shouldn't judge this cd by that one statement alone. Not one, but yes six songs from the hysteria album on this cd is inexcusable to me. This left absolutely no room for any songs from \\"On Through The Night\\". While their debut album doesn't really sound like any of their later music I still feel that it should have been represented by at least one or two songs on Vault. D.L. does not compile their best songs from each of their previous albums on Vault. <BR><BR>     To me, a greatest hits album should compile the best of all their previous albums. I'm not just talking about D.L. here either; I'm talking about any band that wants to make a greatest hits album. That is one of the reasons why I rated Vault with three stars. The 2nd reason I rated Vault with three stars is because some of the songs on Vault were shortened. It is good because it allows them to make room for more songs. It is bad because when songs are shortened i.e. Rocket, they lose the \\"meat.\\"<BR><BR>Finally my 3rd reason for rating Vault with 3 stars, can simply be put in three words: too many ballads. I'm not saying ballads are a terrible thing, but that's overkill.. Again, this comes back to the hysteria overload topic I mentioned earlier. Another point I want to make about greatest hits cds, they should be well rounded. By that, I mean that the greatest hits cd should have songs that equally represent the band.<BR><BR>Ok now I will break down each song and justify my reason why I think it should be on the cd or not be.<BR><BR>1. Pour Some Sugar On Me - This song definitely earned its spot on Vault. I have no problem with it. <BR><BR>2. Photograph - Again, definitely earned its spot. No problem here. <BR><BR>3. Love Bites - One of many ballads on Vault, D.L. should have placed them all on a second cd along with Vault. But as far as the song itself, brilliant lyrics, really hits the heart. <BR><BR>4. Let's Get Rocked - This song is starting to hint toward their \\"pop\\" attitude but doesn't quite make it there. Definitely has a unique approach. <BR><BR>5. Two Steps Behind (acoustic version) - Ok I have a major problem with this one. Since there are two versions of this song (other being electric) they should have obviously placed both on the album. For example, place the acoustic version with the other ballads, and the electric with the other rockers.<BR><BR>6. Animal - I have some mixed feelings about this song. It doesn't really fit well when you place it along with the rest of the songs. It's right up there with the caliber of \\"Let's Get Rocked.\\"<BR><BR>7. Foolin - Correct me if I'm wrong but I think this ballad is one of the ones that started it all for D.L.'s many ballads to come. I think it fits well with the other ballads on Vault. <BR><BR>8. Rocket - This song got really butchered in Vault. It lost nearly two minutes of instrumental. What was D.L. thinking? <BR><BR>9. When Love and Hate Collide - Ok I like this song a lot. I don't understand why a lot of people say this is just another mediocre ballad. It's one of their newer ballads so this could be why. This song definitely hits home for lots and that's why it is one of my favorites. <BR><BR>10. Armageddon It - This song is just plain hilarious. Listen to it a few times and watch the music video and you will see what I mean.<BR><BR>11. Have You Ever Needed Someone So Bad? - Girls really love this song and D.L. doesn't know why. Well it's obvious guys! It is a very sentimental song with emotional lyrics that's bound to break anyone into tears. This song really hits home for me.<BR><BR>12. Rock of Ages - Definitely a ROCK N ROLL song if I ever heard one. KISS and TWISTED SISTER are proud. <BR><BR>13. Hysteria - This song I have mixed feelings about. It doesn't really fit well with the ballads. Don't get me wrong it's an awesome song but it just feels out of place on Vault, like Animal.<BR><BR>14. Miss You In A Heartbeat - D.L. did a smart move placing this song right next to Bringin On The Heartbreak. While it is the softer song of the two, I think it is the more overlooked song of the two.<BR><BR>15. Bringing On The Heartbreak - I have recently begun liking this song after I bought High N Dry. When I first heard it on Vault, I really pushed it aside and really just concentrated on the first half of the cd. Now I know what I have been missing by skipping this song. Everybody DON'T MAKE THE SAME MISTAKE YOU'LL BE KICKING YOURSELF!<BR><BR>To conclude, Vault is a great album to start out your collection with if you are a first time listener of D.L. It may not give you the opportunity to listen to a well-rounded collection of their music but it will definitely get you started nonetheless. If you start your collection with Vault I HIGHLY recommend you check out their other albums. In any event use Vault for starters but once you get your collection going, put it aside and enjoy the long ride on through the night.

B00004Y9PP|4.0|What an amazing movie! A fabulous if relatively unknown cast of characters headlined by one star (Vin Diesel) brings this movie to life. There is the docking pilot-turned-captain (Frys) who attempts to save the survivors, and working with her is a mercenary who cons his way around as a police officer (Johns) trying to bring a cold-blooded, brilliant killer (Riddick) back to civilization. <br />After the untimely and horrific deaths of a miner, and a child of a holy man, the survivors realize that they aren't alone. The planet is inhabited by some blood-thirsty avian/reptile beasts who only come out when the suns go down. This may sound cheesy, since most \\"beasts\\" are afraid of the dark, but in this case, the sun never comes back up...the world goes dark in a total solar eclipse that is supposed to last 22 years.<br />Human nature comes into play as the survivors must fight through the dark to survive. Their only weapon is light, and the only ticket off the dark planet is an old abandoned skiff that has been derelict for years. The complexity of the charaters, and the stunning shots of the desolate wasteland make this film a nightmare come true.

B000002H33|5.0|If Metallica's debut Kill'em All pioneered thrash metal, then their third album Master of Puppets perfected it. It was on this record that the band basically put it all together (the aggression of Kill'em All and the maturity of Ride The Lightning), while improving both the songwriting and musicianship tremendously. The result is a truly amazing album that must not be missed by metal fans or even non-metal fans.<br />The first thing that's apparent on this record is James Hetfield's vocal performance. It is here that he finally sounds fully confident and ready for action. Kirk Hammett's guitar work is also simply astounding, with some amazing solos and excellent interplay with Hetfield's rhythm guitar leads. Lars Ulrich's drumming (while admittedly the least impressive aspect of the album) is rock solid, and Cliff Burton, of course, shows there has yet to be a bassist that matches both his skill and his passion.<br />Here's a rundown of each track:<br />1. Battery - Master of Puppets opens with what's IMO its best song. Battery (like RTL's Fight Fire With Fire) begins with a somewhat Spanish-sounding guitar melody before going into an all out metal assault. Lars Ulrich's drumming really shines here (especially his near perfect timing), and Kirk Hammett's solo will litterally blow you away. In other words, Battery is breathtaking from start to finish, and leads perfectly into...<br />2. Master of Puppets - A long time anthem for Metallica fans and with good reason. Master of Puppets features one of the most memorable riffs Metallica has ever written, mixed with a neat (if somewhat sad-sounding) acoustic interlude and a rocking solo courtesy of Kirk Hammett. The interplay between lyrics and instrumentation is especially amazing as each tone and riff in this song fits perfectly with the changing vocal tones and lyrics. Brilliant track.<br />3. The Thing That Should Not Be - A dark, mid-tempo track inspired by H.P. Lovecraft. The main highlight is, once again, the nearperfect interplay between James' vocal tones and the instrumental melody (alternating between electric and acoustic). Cool solo, too. <br />4. Welcome Home (Sanitarium) - The closest Puppetz really gets to a ballad. The song opens with a somewhat mysterious acoustic melody really reminding you of life in an insane assylum (which is what the song is about), before going into some amazing well-crafted lyrics and a very heavy chorus. The ending is especially amazing with the way Kirk Hammett produces a set of solos that somehow remind you of the pain these assylents are feeling. Great track.<br />5. Disposable Heroes - This song IMO stands right next to Battery as the best song on MOP. The machine-gun riff flat out rocks, as does Kirk Hammett's solo at the very middle and Lar's Ulrich's drum crash towards the end. James' lyrics are also quite good here (sung with an incredible amount of anger). Brilliant track. <br />6. Leper Messiah - This is probably the only track on Master of Puppets that I didn't much care for. Contrary to popular myth, Leper Messiah is not an anti-religious song but an attack on these \\"televangelists\\" that were plaguing the airwaves in the late eighties. Unfortunately, the main riff is somewhat grating and James' lyrics sound a bit too dramatic in parts. The speedier part in the middle is pretty good though.<br />7. Orion - Easilly one of the most creative songs Metallica has ever written. It is in this song that Cliff Burton's bass guitaring really shines, with him producing both lead guitar melodies and background riffs almost flawlessly. James Hetfield's rhythm guitaring is also quite good.<br />8. Damage, Inc. - Master of Puppets closes with a bang. Damage, Inc. is a lightning quick thrash song with some mind blowing lead guitar work and some of Lar's Ulrich's best drumming. I especially like the little \\"heavy metal march\\" in the begining.<br />All in all, with the exception of may be Leper Messiah, Master of Puppets is a masterpiece from start to finish. If you haven't heard any of Metallica's thrash material, this is a great album to start with. The band's newer material is very good (for what it is), but Master of Puppets will forever be remembered as the album that defined Metallica as one of the greatest bands of not only the eighties, but all time.
B00005JLXE|4.0|\\"Daredevil\\" is AWESOME if you like the comic, but it doesn't shut out those that just want to see the newest Affleck, J. Garner, or Farrell pic, either. Another reviewer mentioned &quot;the desired environment&quot; within which to experience the album, and let's just say a trance-inducing one is the best: the desired effect is what you get, thus sayeth George Clinton. B00006DEFA|4.0|Amadeus was one of those films that got way more Oscars than any movie deserves, but it still stands up as high-gloss entertainment.  The main problem is and will forever be Peter Shaffer's conception of the story; nothing and nobody will ever persuade me that Antonio Salieri had murderous designs on W.A. Mozart.  But that doesn't really matter.  View it as a splendid evening's entertainment, and don't delve too deeply into the specious philosophising.<br />Much of the brilliance was in the casting.  F. Murray Abraham is perfect as Salieri.  Saul Zaentz mischievously suggests, in the accompanying making-of documentary, that this is because Abraham is a bit of a Salieri himself - a hard-working, talented performer who has prevented himself from being really outstanding by his suspicion that he hasn't had enough breaks.  Sounds about right to me.  Abraham seethes with jealousy throughout, and when he's required to acknowledge Mozart's talent, then and only then does the mask drop and he becomes humble.  Tom Hulce's high-energy, giggling Mozart is spot-on, in that Mozart displayed little of his own genius in his personal life.  Elizabeth Berridge (as Stanzi) turns out to have been a late replacement for Meg Tilly, who tore a ligament playing football with some Prage street kids.  It was a lucky accident.  Berridge's enormous eyes, guileless American accent and disarming directness makes her a focus of the movie.  Simon Callow, who was the original Mozart on stage, pops up in an early film role as librettist Emmanuel Schikaneder.  <br />The real focus is of course Mozart's music.  One of the reasons why there are no real stars in the film is because the music is meant to be better than any of them.  The Dolby 5.1 sounds fab, although extremely loud.  But my personal favourite turn is Jeffrey Jones, showing early evidence of comic genius as the Emperor, a man just about intelligent enough to realise that he's the thickest person in the room, but so much more powerful than anyone else that this seldom bothers him.  His recurring vocal tic of \\"Mmmm...hm\\", whenever anyone says anything that he disagrees with, is sublime.  Real trivia fans watch out: the pasty-faced, red-nosed maidservant of the Mozarts, alternately spying on them for Salieri and sobbing that she doesn't want to work for them anymore, is a very young Cynthia Nixon of \\"Sex and the City\\" fame.  <br />It's a great night in.  And the funny thing is, I don't even like Mozart's music.

B000002GQG|5.0|With the huge success of their landmark classical-meets-rock album, 1967's &quot;Days Of Future Passed,&quot; and it's smash hit single, &quot;Nights In White Satin,&quot; the Moody Blues had beaten the odds &amp; successfully transformed from the rhythm &amp; blues combo of &quot;Go Now&quot; fame, to the masterful progressive-rock band known the world over. For the follow-up disc, 1968's &quot;In Search Of The Lost Chord,&quot; the Moodies decided to retain the classical instruments from their previous hit album, with one major difference: they would play all the instruments themselves, including cello, oboe, harp, harpsicord, and, for a touch of Indian-flavored music, sitar. &quot;In Search Of The Lost Chord&quot; is arguably the Moody Blues' most psychedelic album, but it is also one of their all-time greats. Bassist John Lodge's rockin' &quot;Ride My See-Saw,&quot; and flautist Ray Thomas' wonderful ode to Timothy Leary, &quot;Legend Of A Mind,&quot; remain Moody Blues concert staples to this day. There's also Thomas' playful &quot;Dr. Livingstone, I Presume,&quot; the experimental delights of Lodge's &quot;House Of Four Doors&quot; (with &quot;Legend Of A Mind&quot; sandwiched within it), guitarist Justin Hayward's beautiful &quot;Voices In The Sky,&quot; &quot;Visions Of Paradise,&quot; and &quot;The Actor,&quot; keyboardist Mike Pinder's spacious &quot;The Best Way To Travel,&quot; and the spiritual &quot;Om,&quot; and drummer Graeme Edge's fine poetry in the forms of &quot;Departure&quot; and &quot;The Word.&quot; Marvelously written, played, &amp; sung by the band, handsomely produced by Tony Clarke, and remastered for superior sound quality, &quot;In Search Of The Lost Chord&quot; remains one of the Moody Blues' finest works.

B00000DFTG|4.0|I never much cared for Black Sabbath.  Listening in the '70s, I thought their music sounded vague and sludgy compared to, say, Led Zep (which in addition to being a standout band had one of rock's greatest and least-recognized producers in Jimmy Page).  This live record has converted me: the mix and mastering is perfect, the rhythm section simply lays waste to the surroundings, and Tony Iommi sounds like a one-man satanic symphony on guitar.  As for Ozzy, several reviews note that he's lost some of his upper vocal register.  What a relief!  The keening screech is downplayed, and with the rest of the band gearing down to accommodate him, the music sounds even darker and more dramatic.  Ozzy can't really sing, technically speaking, but he's almost tuneful here.  The band's performance is nicely sloppy at points, tight and relentless at others.  Overall, &quot;Reunion&quot; is a near-classic live album that finally convinces me Black Sabbath deserve their place in the pantheon.

B000002B1M|4.0|After his breakthrough with the instant classic Illmatic, It Was Written was one of the most awaited albums in 1996, which turned out to be a roller coster year for rap music. Nas returns in this more mature, introspective album to prove the critics correct that he could sustain his crown of King of New York with the increasing number of competitors such as Mobb Deep, the forthcoming Jay-Z and the established Notorious B.I.G. Although not as raw and to the point as Illmatic, Nas still expresses himself well throughout the album, an official LP of 14 tracks. <br />The production level of this album exceeds that of the lyrical as Nas does not seem to be as focused as on the previous Illmatic. The shots are still called by DJ Premier but with newcomers such as Havoc (of Mobb Deep) and L.E.S who provide the album with a different sound. In front of the beats enters Nas' ever lasting lyrical flow. No hesitations, stutters or pauses halt the album as Nas shows his lyrical ability is still at the top. <br />The album's strongest point is its beginning with the single release of \\"The Message\\" and \\"Street Dreams\\", with Nas rapping from an experienced, street wise gangster. Next comes \\"I Gave You Power\\" rapped through a pistol's perspective of how it is just to be used and thrown away like nothing. Nas' evidence of his sustained flow is shown in \\"Watch Dem Niggas\\" and \\"Take It In Blood\\", which happen to be the two best tracks on the LP. From this point onwards, the album takes a downhill direction, although the partnership of Nas AND Dr Dre proves to be a working formula in \\"Nas Is Coming\\" an analysis and evaluation of the East/West Coast rap war being a waste of time. The one other significant track on the album, which again shows Nas at his best, is \\"If I Ruled The World\\" with backing vocals supplied by Fugees member Lauryn Hill. <br />As with every Nas album, It Was Written was compared to his \\"classic\\" Illmatic, although not as real or philosophical, this 1996 release attains platinum status among loyal Nas fans, definitely an overlooked album.
0440180295|5.0|This `anti-war book,' as Vonnegut himself has called it, focuses on the life of a World War II prisoner of war named Billy Pilgrim.  Pilgrim (along with Vonnegut, the narrator) was present when Dresden was bombed and destroyed by the Allied forces, killing far more people than the atomic bombs in Hiroshima or Nagasaki.  The bombing, and the ensuing ruinous carnage of the former city, serve to show the horrors of war, and the violence and destruction of innocent lives which are sometimes a price of the bloody game of war.<BR> <BR>But this is not your typical anti-war book.  Vonnegut does not openly criticize the Allies for bombing Dresden--in fact, one of his characters points out that, at the time, it seemed like it had to be done.  Another, more subtle consequence of war is the focus of this book, however, and this consequence is exemplified in the mental state of Billy Pilgrim.  Billy thinks he has stepped outside of time, and no longer sees things chronologically.  Instead, the novel constantly jumps back and forth in time to different events in Billy's life, including a supposed alien kidnapping.  Though the book treats these time jumps as real, enough hints are given for the skeptical reader to doubt.  The war left Billy's life in shambles, and he spends the bulk of the novel trying to make sense of it all (hence the non-linear narrative).<BR> <BR>Vonnegut seems to be showing us two ugly sides to war.  The first is the side we all know by now--the innocent victims, the meaningless slaughter, the terrible destruction.  But the second, subtler side can only be seen in Billy Pilgrim's character, and it seems this is another horrible effect of war.  War causes carnage and bloodshed while it is occurring, but it also has long term effects.  Depression, anxiety, and many other forms of mental illness can come about because of war, as Vonnegut so eloquently points out in this novel.  This is considered to be one of the greatest modernist novels of the 20th century, and with good reason.  I highly recommend this unique take on war.
B00000JLWW|4.0|Dicappio and Winslet may not have the depth necessary for their parts. The director's treatment in these respects may not carry too much weight and as such the movie may not be as convincing as some would have expected. But as a commercial film this is a big success.<br />The story itself may well be a true reflection of what had actually transpired. The director started the film with a recent exploration of the sunken Titanic leading the viewers deep into the ocean to be followed by an interview with the 102 years old survivor, Rose, the heroine of the movie, to make it ring as true as a documentary.<br />The grandeur of Titanic was particularly well captured. The life of the upper class life on board was convincingly conveyed. Even the life of the lower class was well portrayed, and when things are not quite unrealistic, they have good purposes to serve, touching up the general atmostphere making it more juicy... etc. <br />The two contrasting scenes, the dinner party of the upper class and the party of the poor were well handled. These are one of the mosting exciting part of the movie. The Captain, who was so convinced and so proud of the unsinkability of the ship and then the musicians who hung on till the last minute... they are so telling and touching. The rhythm of the movie is quite fast and never boring.<br />What more can we expect from a commercial movie like this? Recommended.
B000002KOQ|4.0|Joni's first two albums had their moments, but &quot;Ladies Of The Canyon&quot; was really the first time that people began to realize<BR>that here was a major talent who would come to define their generation.  Released in early 1970, the album sums up many of the hopes, dreams and disappointments of the decade which had just passed, and as a result remains one of her best-loved works.<BR>For the first time, she used piano nearly as equally as she did the acoustic guitar, moving her sound away from pure folk and into a more sophisticated singer-songwriter savvy, with her lyrics moving into deeper, more mature territory as well.<br />Tracks like &quot;Morning Morgantown&quot;, &quot;For Free&quot; and &quot;Ladies Of The Canyon&quot; contain a purity of imagery, vocal and music that is <BR>just unparalleled; they run like water that has been filtered for the clearest taste.  Which makes the darker tracks such as &quot;The Arrangment&quot; and &quot;The Priest&quot; sound even starker by contrast, and also foreshadow the breakdown documented on the next album.  The three most popular and well-known songs close the album: &quot;Big Yellow Taxi&quot; matches a bouncing rhythm against<BR>a rather cynical ecology rant (watch the way she says &quot;a pink hotel, a boutique and a swingin' hot-spot!&quot; with an exaggerated,<BR>slick adman's sense of excitement), &quot;Woodstock&quot; is a slow, meditative attempt to poetically sum up the mood of the festival she came so close to attending in airy, transcendent vocal<BR>phrasings (and IMO far superior to the more commercial CSNY version), while &quot;The Circle Game&quot; is a folkie standard sung with a chorus that marks a gentle nod to the passing of time.<br />Overall, &quot;Ladies Of The Canyon&quot; paints an optimistic portrait of its time, where the problems of external and internal pollution<BR>are quietly resolved by the extreme purity of its sound.  Coming as it does only one album before the torrid &quot;Blue&quot; makes this<BR>even more revealing, and certainly essential.

B00008LDPU|5.0|Having been lucky enough to have seen the 9 episodes, I can say that the Wachowskys are the best thing to happen to movies in a long time, and this generation's creativity icons in Hollywood.  That they could take The Matrix's success and share the wealth with this incredible project, giving so many people a chance to showcase their talent while giving the world of The Matrix an exciting new medium in which to express itself, shows their brilliance, and that they are no one-trick ponies.<br />I'll start by commenting on the overwhelming rave reviews for \\"Final Flight of the Osiris\\".  In truth, with all the hype, when I finally did see it, I was sorely disappointed.  Technically, yes, it is brilliant, as I feel is the usual with Square's work (definitely including the Final Fantasy film).  But the execution is way too juvenile.  The initial fight scene and the pipe acrobatics (while the fate of humanity is ticking) scene are so ridiculous and juvenile that they are almost embarrassing to watch.  You'll know when you see them.  Suffice it to say that everyone will be awed by the CGI quality, but its overall appeal will only lie with the pre-teen crowd.  Good action, fabulous animation, but disappointing plot execution.<br />The best of the 9 are, in my opinion, the two Second Renaissance parts and Kid's Story.  They are the most entertaining, bold, intelligent, and artistically brilliant of the bunch.  The dark Second Renaissance will bring chills down your spine, and the touching Kid's Story takes a basically action-oriented short and enhances it with brilliant artistic shifts and terrific music.  <br />The worst of the bunch is, without hesitation, Program.  It is the one regrettable mar on an otherwise brilliant DVD.  Very derivative and juvenile, both artistically and plot-wise, it's the only one that wasn't brave enough to examine The Matrix's world in any real way...it is just a very weak, over-the-top Samurai fight scene that just happens to take place in a Construct program.  It's nothing that isn't dime-a-dozen with TV-cartoon-quality anime, and the fact that the Program team wasted the incredible opportunity to push the envelope (that the other shorts took advantage of), is a real shame.  Program does not belong on this DVD.<br />That aside, however, The Animatrix is one of the most exciting and different projects to come out of the Hollywood machine in a long time.  It is incredibly entertaining, often brilliant, and vrey reasonably priced.  And as an aside, the Wachowskys and the incredible anime talent they shared their good fortune with, all deserve your support.  This is the no-brainer purchase of the year, especially (though not only) for anime and Matrix fans.

B00005QDW5|2.0|If you're a Floyd completist who's just gotta have When the Tigers Broke Free on cd, that's one thing.  But if you're a casual fan looking for a concise package of essential Pink Floyd, one has yet to be made.  There are 26 tracks on Echoes, a whopping 10 of which are either from the short-lived and over-hyped Syd Barrett era or from the post-Waters albums.  In other words, almost 40% of Echoes (by track, not time) is a mix of whimsical 1967 ditties that sound like nothing else they would ever do, and David Gilmour solo material that he understandably chose to release under the more lucrative Pink Floyd name (well, not quite: Marooned is a Rick Wright instrumental from the post-Waters days, but it's also possibly the most baffling inclusion on this collection). There is not enough space remaining on these two short discs to do justice to the band's classic years, and even a fair chunk of that is squandered on questionable picks like Fletcher Memorial Home, Happiest Days of Our Lives, Sheep, Great Gig in the Sky, and When the Tigers Broke Free (a rarity only included to snare the folks who've already got all of the albums)....
B000089RVX|4.0|I was incredibly skeptical of Evanescence, considering that their popularity stemmed from their overplayed single off the Daredevil soundtrack. It's a real pity that they can't flood the rest of the album onto today's radio stations: it's definitely better than most rock people are into.<br />The biggest statement the album makes is obviously through vocals; however, its not what is said, but rather HOW its said. Amy Lee has an incredible voice, hands down. She isn't afraid of using variation, and she can jump from sweet nothings to a low, definitive growl in a heartbeat.<br />Knowing this about her voice, the band isn't afraid to contrast the voice with some powerful chords. The band has no problem smashing on the strings, but the lyrics aren't anything to be amazed about. Then again, this style of rock isn't aiming for any meaningful revelations or deep truths--it rocks, and rocks hard. There's nothing uplifting to be found here, but don't confuse uplifting with worthwhile: Evanescence put out a good record here, a hard album that easily stands out from the rest.
