B00008WG3U|3.0|As a die-hard NOFX fan, i have to admit that i'm a bit disapointed with this record. from the title, one would think that this would be another scathing political commentary stemming from the same vein as \\"the decline\\" e.p., but unfortunately, none of the politically driven songs on this record can hold a finger to \\"the decline\\", in fact, much of the band's older political material from less politically-driven records (songs like \\"perfect government\\", \\"dig\\" and \\"the bag\\") is much stronger than anything on \\"the war on errorism\\". i only make this point because in the last year or so, fat mike has been making his political opinions much more public than he has in years past, launching punkvoter.com and making numerous anti-bush statements through fat wreck chords newsletters. given the band's ultra-liberal stance and the current state of the world, i was hoping for much stronger political material, instead, i got the disturbingly poppy and lyrically dull \\"franco-unamerican\\", which sounds disturbingly similar to \\"quart in session\\" from 1997s \\"so long, and thanks for all the shoes\\". not to say that there aren't good political songs on this record; \\"the irrationality of rationality\\" and \\"american errorist\\" (i hate hate haters) both stand out as two of this album's better cuts, but by NOFX standards, they aren't anything special. another suprising thing about this seemingly ultra-political record is the number of light-hearted \\"fun\\" songs that were put on it. the band's last effort, \\"pump up the valuum\\", was crammed full of songs that could never be taken seriously, but were unarguably hilarious. for a record that features a clown faced bush on an american flag backdrop for a cover, \\"the war on errorism\\" has more than its fair share of such material. songs like \\"she's nubs\\", \\"mattersville\\", \\"medio-core\\" and \\"anarchy camp\\" are all pretty typical of NOFX humor, but they seem out of place on this record.<br />the album opens with \\"the seperation of church and skate\\", which isprobably my favorite song on this album. the song takes a serious shot at the bubble gum \\"punk\\" bands that have taken the spotlight in recent years, (new found glory, good charlotte, sum41, etc.) fat mike asks the listener \\"when did punk rock become so safe?\\" and speaks the truth with \\"these f--king bands all sound the same\\"...very true. \\"she's nubs\\" is definetly the funniest song on this record (the tale of a girl with no arms or legs)...\\"decom-poseur\\" and \\"we got two jealousa agains\\" are both pretty good songs, again, nothing spectacular, especially for NOFX. \\"anarchy camp\\" is one of the most uninteresting song ideas this band has ever come up with, but they make up for it by making it the most musically interesting song on the album, spicing it up with some nice sax leads, keyboards and kickin ska riffs...\\"13 stitches\\" and \\"whoops, i od'd\\" both have a softer sound than you're used to hearing from NOFX, and both sacrifice rhyming for the sake of telling a story. \\"regaining unconsciousness\\" is the albums last politically driven song, and it also stands out as one of the disc's better tracks.<br />all in all, i can't call this a bad record by any means, but by NOFX standards, it's nothing special. of the band's last six full length albums, this is definetly the weakest, but again, it's certainly not a terrible album. it has it's fair share of good songs, but there really isn't one truely fantastic NOFX banger to be found on the album. fat mike's lyricsism on this record was also somewhat disapointing. when you think that this is the same guy who wrote \\"the decline\\", it's suprising that the ultra-conservative bush administration and the rampant nationalism in the united states hasn't inspired him to write some lyrically spectacular songs. <br />so yeah, if you're a die hard NOFX fan, you should probably pick this album up, but don't be suprised when you find it doesn't measure up to \\"punk in drublic\\" or \\"white trash, two heebs and a bean\\"...if you're not one of theNOFX faithful, you should probably listen to this record before you buy it.
